snippet.textDisplay:
Okay, here's my five cents based on usage of Ububtu:

"Update when you want" - false. I was forced to restart PC and update to use it.

"Performance " - again false. Windows 10 is far snappier than Ubuntu on my cheap notebook.

Lastly, ubuntu had no clue about the drivers for the WiFi card my notebook has and I had to do lots of research and download third party ones from someone's git repo.
snippet.textOriginal:
Okay, here's my five cents based on usage of Ububtu:

"Update when you want" - false. I was forced to restart PC and update to use it.

"Performance " - again false. Windows 10 is far snappier than Ubuntu on my cheap notebook. 

Lastly, ubuntu had no clue about the drivers for the WiFi card my notebook has and I had to do lots of research and download third party ones from someone's git repo.

snippet.textOriginal: Thought the title was "10 way Linus is just better!"

snippet.textDisplay:
I had a 'Linux Guy' as a professor in college once. He was the most unorganized human being I have ever meet and the reason. He did everything in command lines (that he never bothered to explain). he wanted to use the most efficient ways possible to teach and in the end, we didn't learn anything and had to teach each other. I and my classmates would spend hours combing through the Linux environment he forced us to use just to find the correct files for our assignments. And of course, he would give them nonsensical names or edit them instead of making new files ensuring that any examples would be erased. All the while trash-talking Windows and macOS. I don't think he realized he was actually making other OS's look great and insuring none of us would want to work with Linux again. But my very next CS class we had to basically put all of what we learned into practice with a Raspberry pi and our own version of Linux. But the professor wasn't some wired Linux shut in and was actually willing to use other OS's if it helped us learn. It ended up being the most fun group project I ever did in school.


So basically Linux can be great but only when its users have the time to get off their conspiracy theory soapboxes and explain how the damn thing works.
snippet.textOriginal:
I had a 'Linux Guy' as a professor in college once. He was the most unorganized human being I have ever meet and the reason. He did everything in command lines (that he never bothered to explain). he wanted to use the most efficient ways possible to teach and in the end, we didn't learn anything and had to teach each other. I and my classmates would spend hours combing through the Linux environment he forced us to use just to find the correct files for our assignments. And of course, he would give them nonsensical names or edit them instead of making new files ensuring that any examples would be erased. All the while trash-talking Windows and macOS. I don't think he realized he was actually making other OS's look great and insuring none of us would want to work with Linux again. But my very next CS class we had to basically put all of what we learned into practice with a Raspberry pi and our own version of Linux. But the professor wasn't some wired Linux shut in and was actually willing to use other OS's if it helped us learn. It ended up being the most fun group project I ever did in school.


So basically Linux can be great but only when its users have the time to get off their conspiracy theory soapboxes and explain how the damn thing works.

snippet.textDisplay:
Linux is honestly great. I set up my home server with ubuntu. The only Problems i ran in to where the fact that pretty much no GUI Remote Desktop kinda thing seems to work with Windows... so Console it was, which is a major pain for a Linux noob... And also while packet managers are great, somehow 80% of what i needed wasnt in any of them, so i had to add it. And butchering stuff together by taking parts out of half a dozen tutorials doesnt help either... Linux has a super steep lerning curve in my oppinion.
But once you have fought your way through all of this it just works :) Unlike my Windows server before i could let it run for a month on its own, come back and everything was still running. On Windows it would have rebooted 3 times and installed at least one update that would break either the network detection or SMB altogether...
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Not even necessarily multiple. I still have my 32GB USB laying around with a bunch of different linux based tools and a few distros. Some distros for lightweight things and simple tasks that don't take long to load and a few bigger ones with a bunch of baked in tools that can come in handy. So literally one USB stick, if big enough, can be almost everything you need. Only drawback is that if you need to update some or even just one of those tools or distros your whole USB is, during that process, out of service XD
snippet.textOriginal: Not even necessarily multiple. I still have my 32GB USB laying around with a bunch of different linux based tools and a few distros. Some distros for lightweight things and simple tasks that don't take long to load and a few bigger ones with a bunch of baked in tools that can come in handy. So literally one USB stick, if big enough, can be almost everything you need. snippet.textDisplay: Just an aside, I've been using linux since 1990, and it's had virtual desktops at least since then. Early 200's? HAH! You're at least a decade behind. And back then, you had to know EVERYTHING about your hardware, you could actually destroy your monitor if you put in the wrong scan frequencies. It's gotten MUCH easier since then.
snippet.textOriginal: Just an aside, I've been using linux since 1990, and it's had virtual desktops at least since then. Early 200's? HAH! You're at least a decade behind. And back then, you had to know EVERYTHING about your hardware, you could actually destroy your monitor if you put in the wrong scan frequencies. It's gotten MUCH easier since then.

snippet.textDisplay:
had my bachelors thesis code running on a jupyter notebook on a linux server, hit ram limit once, server crashed and needed two days of fixing. not the first linux crash ive experienced that led to no reboot. oh and driver support. opencl on a graphics card older than 5 years? not with a current release. xubuntu on a slow laptop? slower than windows 10. touch support with something like ubuntu? rudimentary at best.
i do think linux has its merits, but there are loads of issues.

i do think linux has its merits, but there are loads of issues.

snippet.textDisplay: I read the title 10 ways Linus is just better
snippet.textOriginal: I read the title *10 ways Linus is just better*

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel like this video is not really accurate, I mean it's only saying why Linux are better but there's also things that are worse, I like Linux but to be completely transparent, it's not the best OS, no matter the distro, themes and customization that you get from Linux, there's things that for me and I'm sure that for others too, are a big deal like no scrolling down with your scroll wheel, not a lot of help when you start and stuff like that.
When i wanted to try Linux for the first time i chose Debian because it was the most 'stable' Linux distro from what I've heard and It was pretty good not gonna lie but there was stuff that you get so used to from Windows (and probably from Mac too but I don't know for sure because I've never used Mac) that is just so hard to get rid off, problems like when you are pure new you need to google legit everything for hours and even days sometimes to know what to do and when Linus said "you can just execute a command to download something" it's not that simple half of the time, you need to know the exact name of the file that you want to download and sometimes you might download random things that you don't even know what they do and some times you have to search for hours to find the correct name for something so small that you can just search it on Windows and click "download" and the gaming experience is a bit tricky with Lutris and Proton and Wine and for someone that is purely new on Linux is just going to give a big old headache, maybe 2 if they're unlucky.
Not everything is better on Linux, there's good things and bad things but again, no OS is perfect.
snippet.textOriginal:
I feel like this video is not really accurate, I mean it's only saying why Linux are better but there's also things that are worse, I like Linux but to be completely transparent, it's not the best OS, no matter the distro, themes and customization that you get from Linux, there's things that for me and I'm sure that for others too, are a big deal like no scrolling down with your scroll wheel, not a lot of help when you start and stuff like that.
When i wanted to try Linux for the first time i chose Debian because it was the most 'stable' Linux distro from what I've heard and It was pretty good not gonna lie but there was stuff that you get so used to from Windows (and probably from Mac too but I don't know for sure because I've never used Mac) that is just so hard to get rid off, problems like when you are pure new you need to google legit everything for hours and even days sometimes to know what to do and when Linus said "you can just execute a command to download something" it's not that simple half of the time, you need to know the exact name of the file that you want to download and sometimes you might download random things that you don't even know what they do and some times you have to search for hours to find the correct name for something so small that you can just search it on Windows and click "download" and the gaming experience is a bit tricky with Lutris and Proton and Wine and for someone that is purely new on Linux is just going to give a big old headache, maybe 2 if they're unlucky.
Not everything is better on Linux, there's good things and bad things but again, no OS is perfect.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dear children...Linus might have made shiny flashy video, but Linux is no silver bullet for all your problems. GNU/Linux is just an OS that will allow you to do things, even those you should not be normally doing. It is only as good as the end users ability to handle it and it can be more fucked solution than windows if used improperly. It will allow you to do quite cool stuff but on the other hand it can ruin your day too.

With that said... go fire up the usb and play around, but do not expect magic ponies fly around and poop rainbows .
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Virtual desktops were old hat in the late 90s. There was IIRC, a version of the enlightenment window manager that let you slide one virtual desktop over another, and then drag windows between them. Though IIRC, the first window manager with virtual desktops was fvwm, and that was around when I first played with Linux circa 1995-96.
snippet.textOriginal: Virtual desktops were old hat in the late 90s. There was IIRC, a version of the enlightenment window manager that let you slide one virtual desktop over another, and then drag windows between them. Though IIRC, the first window manager with virtual desktops was fvwm, and that was around when I first played with Linux circa 1995-96.

snippet.textDisplay: 'Can run on just 16MB RAM, with a gui' -- way back when, (circa 1998), Linux was happily running on a 486 with 4MB RAM, _with a gui_. Another was sitting in the downstairs closet, functioning as NAS and internet router (dialling up to 56k on demand). Those were the days.
snippet.textOriginal: 'Can run on just 16MB RAM, with a gui' -- way back when, (circa 1998), Linux was happily running on a 486 with 4MB RAM, _with a gui_. Another was sitting in the downstairs closet, functioning as NAS and internet router (dialling up to 56k on demand). Those were the days.

snippet.textDisplay: A 1.52% market share for Chrome OS is also significant, considering that it was released in 2011. This should be viewed a secondary win for the Linux community since recent updates are signalling that the OS will embrace more Linux features, possibly opening their closed system to become a fully-fledged distro.
snippet.textOriginal: A 1.52% market share for Chrome OS is also significant, considering that it was released in 2011. This should be viewed a secondary win for the Linux community since recent updates are signalling that the OS will embrace more Linux features, possibly opening their closed system to become a fully-fledged distro.

snippet.textDisplay:
TF2 minimizes instantly from fullscreen with the desktop shortcut Win+h (There's no accidental windows menu popup).
Doesn't seem to work for Proton games, but you can have borderless windowed if you're fine with that.

The file managers are actually nice. Windows still has that old thing.
snippet.textOriginal:
TF2 minimizes instantly from fullscreen with the desktop shortcut Win+h (There's no accidental windows menu popup).
Doesn't seem to work for Proton games, but you can have borderless windowed if you're fine with that.

The file managers are actually nice. Windows still has that old thing.

snippet.textDisplay:
Using Linux as desktop is a bit like modding video games
Nothing is made in consideration of anything else, theres no standardization and you always end up with a janky ass setup
Freeware is cool and all but it never reaches the same quality and usefulness as their corresponding Windows or Mac software (inb4 hurrdurr just run wine)
Reading help sections or even man pages is sometimes futile because not only is the linux "community" an elitist hivemind who thinks "you should just know this stuff" but also because they just dont give a fuck about writing that shit
In the end it might be just as easy to just code everything yourself than try to understand how these neckbeards software even works. Well thats freedom for you.
Just install WSL.
Wanna actually use your pc productively? Use Windows
Wanna use your pc somewhat productively and got money to burn? Use OSX
Wanna build your own system from the ground up, rice that shit with anime tiddies because you are a neckbeard sitting in your mothers basement and got nothing better to do? Use Linux.


(not bashing on linux for servers, for that its great)
snippet.textOriginal:
Using Linux as desktop is a bit like modding video games
Nothing is made in consideration of anything else, theres no standardization and you always end up with a janky ass setup
Freeware is cool and all but it never reaches the same quality and usefulness as their corresponding Windows or Mac software (inb4 hurrdurr just run wine)
Reading help sections or even man pages is sometimes futile because not only is the linux "community" an elitist hivemind who thinks "you should just know this stuff" but also because they just dont give a fuck about writing that shit
In the end it might be just as easy to just code everything yourself than try to understand how these neckbeards software even works. Well thats freedom for you.
Just install WSL.
Wanna actually use your pc productively? Use Windows
Wanna use your pc somewhat productively and got money to burn? Use OSX
Wanna build your own system from the ground up, rice that shit with anime tiddies because you are a neckbeard sitting in your mothers basement and got nothing better to do? Use Linux.


(not bashing on linux for servers, for that its great)

snippet.textDisplay: That's a steep learning curve if you want to really be able to navigate around in linux. Just getting things to work back in the day (late 90s) was a huge pain in the ass. I never did get everything running right. Worth it if you're good at that sort of thing and enjoy it , but as a more casual user it was an exercise in frustration.
snippet.textOriginal: That's a steep learning curve if you want to really be able to navigate around in linux. Just getting things to work back in the day (late 90s) was a huge pain in the ass. I never did get everything running right. Worth it if you're good at that sort of thing and enjoy it , but as a more casual user it was an exercise in frustration.
